JUSTWORD	0009	1256	885	1310	911	San
JUSTWORD	0009	1322	885	1475	916	Francisco,
JUSTWORD	0009	1489	886	1626	911	Freeman.
JUSTWORD	0009	272	1091	428	1123	Typescript
JUSTWORD	0009	441	1090	557	1116	received
SPECFONT	0009	441	1090	557	1116	received 
JUSTWORD	0009	571	1091	603	1116	28
JUSTWORD	0009	617	1090	714	1117	March
JUSTWORD	0009	730	1090	791	1116	1981
JUSTWORD	0009	1559	993	1664	1012	FORTER
JUSTWORD	0009	1677	994	1707	1012	M.
JUSTWORD	0009	1721	993	1785	1012	KIER
JUSTWORD	0009	1459	1037	1637	1068	Department
JUSTWORD	0009	1650	1036	1683	1062	of
JUSTWORD	0009	1693	1036	1884	1069	Paleobiology
JUSTWORD	0009	1496	1074	1679	1101	Smithsonian
JUSTWORD	0009	1692	1074	1847	1101	Institution
JUSTWORD	0009	1492	1113	1670	1145	Washington
JUSTWORD	0009	1682	1113	1752	1139	D.C,
JUSTWORD	0009	1766	1113	1851	1139	20560
CENTERED	0001	545	82	1629	123	RAPID EVOLUTION IN ECHINOIDS 
CENTERED	0001	886	185	1284	226	by <b>PORTER M. KIER </b>
CENTERED	0001	324	301	1846	336	Ansritacr. The evolution of the irregular echinoid and <i>of the </i>sand dollar occurred in a very short time. The first 
CENTERED	0001	323	337	1846	372	irregular echinoid appears abruptly in the Early Jurassic (Sinemurian); and by the Toarcian, only ten million 
CENTERED	0001	323	373	1844	406	years later, irregular echinoids possess all the features necessary <i>to </i>permit them to live buried in the sediment. 
CENTERED	0001	323	408	1846	442	The first clypeasteroid appears in the Paleocene. By the middle Eocene its very specialized descendants, the sand 
CENTERED	0001	323	443	1845	476	dollars, have a worldwide distribution. This rapid evolution and diversification seem to result from a sudden 
CENTERED	0001	323	479	1846	515	adaptive breakthrough. The presence of so few intermediates indicates the evolutionary steps must have been 
FOLLOWED	0001	322	518	396	549	<i>large. </i>
CENTERED	0001	321	605	1842	643	Two of the most significant events in the evolution of the echinoids are the development of the 
CENTERED	0001	321	643	1843	679	irregular echinoid and the subsequent appearance of the sand dollar. Both of these events were 
CENTERED	0001	322	681	1842	718	believed <i>to </i>have occurred over a long period of time (Durham 1966, p. U289) but new evidence 
CENTERED	0001	321	721	1842	757	suggests otherwise. The irregular echinoid was assumed to have evolved during the Triassic and 
CENTERED	0001	321	758	1842	795	perhaps during the latter part of the Paleozoic. However, study of the Triassic faunas indicates that 
CENTERED	0001	321	799	1841	836	no irregulars were present then and that the great changes from the regular to the irregular echinoid 
CENTERED	0001	321	837	1840	874	occurred during the early part of the Early Jurassic. Likewise, it was believed (Durham 1966, 
CENTERED	0001	320	877	1840	912	p. U29Q) that the clypeasteroids arose during the Late Cretaceous and Paleocene. New evidence 
CENTERED	0001	321	915	1840	953	suggests that the first clypeasteroid actually appeared in the Paleocene, and that the great evolution to 
CENTERED	0001	630	1048	1531	1075	EVOLUTION OF THE IRREGULAR ECHINOID 
CENTERED	0001	321	1106	1841	1144	The first irregular echinoid, <i>Plesiechinus Itawkinsi </i>Jesionek-Szymanska (text-fig. la), occurs in the 
CENTERED	0001	321	1146	1841	1182	Early Jurassic (Sinemurian). This echinoid, a pygasterid, differs from all other echinoids of the same 
CENTERED	0001	320	1185	1840	1223	age <i>or </i>older in having an asymmetrical test with small tuberculation, short and numerous spines, 
CENTERED	0001	320	1225	1841	1263	diflerentiated pores with the adapical pores larger than the adoral ones, posteriorly eccentric 
CENTERED	0001	319	1264	1845	1302	periproct, and presumably keeled teeth (although the lantern was not found with any specimens of 
CENTERED	0001	355	1342	1840	1381	One might assume that the great changes necessary to derive this irregular echinoid from a regular 
CENTERED	0001	320	1381	1840	1420	form would have taken a very long time. Many workers believe that these changes occurred during 
CENTERED	0001	320	1421	1839	1460	the Triassic or possibly in the Paleozoic. They attributed the lack of intermediates found during the 
CENTERED	0001	319	1461	1838	1498	Triassic to the poor fossil record of that period. However, that does not appear to be the case. 
CENTERED	0001	318	1500	1839	1539	Although it is true that few echinoids are known from the Triassic, particularly from the Early and 
CENTERED	0001	319	1540	1837	1579	Middle Triassic, a prolific echinoid fauna occurs in the Late Triassic St. Cassian beds of Italy. These 
CENTERED	0001	318	1579	1839	1617	beds (Kier 1977b) have been painstakingly searched by Rinaldo Zardini who has found many 
CENTERED	0001	318	1617	1838	1654	complete tests and thousands of fragments. I have searched through all this material and have failed 
CENTERED	0001	318	1657	1838	1695	to find any keeled teeth or any test fragments with the fine tuberculation of an irregular echinoid. As 
CENTERED	0001	318	1696	1838	1734	shown by <i>Kier </i>(1977a), irregular echinoids are much more likely to be preserved than regular 
CENTERED	0001	317	1737	1835	1773	echinoids. Had they been living during St. Cassian time, they should have been preserved as fossils. 
CENTERED	0001	318	1775	1838	1812	Furthermore, no irregular echinoids or any form resembling them have been found in the lowermost 
CENTERED	0001	353	1856	1837	1892	I am convinced that this change from a regular echinoid to <i>Plesiechinus Itawkinsi </i>must have 
CENTERED	0001	317	1895	1837	1931	occurred extremely quickly during the latter part of the Hettangian or early Sinemurian. Evolution 
CENTERED	0001	317	1933	1836	1971	then continued at a rapid rate, because by the Toarcian, still within the Early Jurassic, the cassiduloid 
CENTERED	0001	317	1973	1837	2011	Galeropygus durttorrieri (Paris) (text-fig. lc) has appeared with all the features of an irregular 
CENTERED	0001	325	2133	1829	2167	echinoid. It is more advanced than <i>P. hawkinsi </i>in having a more flattened and elongate test, a more 
CENTERED	0001	325	2172	1828	2210	eccentric periproct, larger adapical pores forming incipient petals, and smaller, more numerous, 
CENTERED	0001	326	2210	1827	2248	tubercles and spines. Its peristome is smaller, elongate, and eccentric anteriorly. There are no gills. 
CENTERED	0001	325	2248	1829	2286	The most profound <i>differences </i>are the lack of a lantern and lantern supports and the presence of well-
CENTERED	0001	361	2328	1829	2366	Presumably, one of the reasons for this rapid evolution was that these changes enabled echinoids to 
CENTERED	0001	326	2366	1830	2405	occupy a habitat not available to them before. They were now able to burrow (Smith 1978) into the 
CENTERED	0001	326	2405	1829	2442	sediment and extract the organic material contained within. Simpson (1944, 1953), and later Stanley 
CENTERED	0001	328	2446	1831	2483	(1979), proposed that a higher taxon arises rapidly through the occurrence of a sudden adaptive 
CENTERED	0001	326	2483	1829	2521	breakthrough. During the Triassic all echinoids apparently lived on the surface of the sea floor and 
CENTERED	0001	326	2522	1829	2559	could not burrow into the sediment. They all had jaws and <i>grooved </i>teeth which were used 
CENTERED	0001	326	2562	1831	2601	(presumably like modern regular echinoids) to tear off and chew organic material which was then 
CENTERED	0001	326	2602	1831	2641	passed into the gut. The small amount of faecal discharge could be easily carried away by water 
CENTERED	0001	326	2641	1830	2678	currents. Most modern irregular echinoids lacking teeth feed differently. They burrow (text-fig. 1) 
CENTERED	0001	893	2753	1333	2787	LOWER JURASSIC 
CENTERED	0001	766	3398	808	3416	<b>*0 </b>
CENTERED	0001	650	3422	778	3440	<b>f 0 0 </b>
CENTERED	0001	676	3446	1118	3466	<b>«0 </b>««r* <b>5 </b>
CENTERED	0001	650	3498	806	3516	<b>5 *o* </b>
CENTERED	0001	651	3522	1164	3541	SHIFTING OF PrpatOME ANTERIORLY~ 
CENTERED	0001	714	3548	930	3566	<b>*» * 5 </b>
CENTERED	0001	810	3574	826	3592	<b>0 </b>
CENTERED	0001	714	3598	950	3616	<b>0 0 ON </b>
CENTERED	0001	651	3622	1303	3642	GROOVED TEETH~ KEELED tttTH~ No TrtTH
CENTERED	0002	355	25	1793	59	mxr-Pto. <b>I. </b>Evolution of the irregular echinoid showing the changes that enabled the echinoid to live buried 
CENTERED	0002	355	60	1792	94	in the substrate. A, an Hettangian regular echinoid such as <i>Diademopsis; </i>n, the earliest known irregular, 
CENTERED	0002	569	96	1580	128	Plesieehinus <i>hawkinsi </i>Jesionek-Szymanska; c, a cassiduloid, <i>Galeropygus.</i>
CENTERED	0002	868	290	1300	316	<b>BXPLANATION OP PLATB </b>1 
CENTERED	0002	336	346	1836	381	Figs. 1-5. Togocyamus seefriedi (Oppenheim). Paleocene, Ekekoro Formation, Ekekoro quarry, 55 km north-
CENTERED	0003	1560	2038	1596	2062	<b>Xi </b>~
CENTERED	0004	1141	1830	1200	1865	'"h.ij
CENTERED	0005	1241	1434	1268	1450	"4 
CENTERED	0005	291	2948	1857	2992	into the sediment, collect large amounts of sediment with their tube-feet, and pass it through the gut 
CENTERED	0005	291	2988	1856	3035	while extracting the organic material. The sediment is then expelled through the anus (periproct). 
CENTERED	0005	292	3029	1857	3072	Most of the differences between an irregular and regular echinoid relate to these differences in mode 
CENTERED	0005	329	3110	1858	3158	The posterior migration of the periproct made it possible for the irregular echinoid to leave this 
CENTERED	0005	293	3151	1859	3200	large volume of discharged sediment in its trail rather than over its dorsal surface. At the same time 
CENTERED	0005	294	3191	1863	3240	that the periproct migrated, most irregular echinoids increased the oxygen-gathering capability of 
CENTERED	0005	294	3233	1859	3279	their dorsal tube-feet by greatly broadening them. The result was the formation of the 'petals' so 
CENTERED	0005	294	3274	1860	3323	typical of most irregulars. Specialized tube-feet were also produced around the mouth. They were 
CENTERED	0005	566	3423	1589	3457	EVOLUTION OF THE CLYPEASTEROID ECHINOID
CENTERED	0006	295	19	1860	67	The first clypeasteroid echinoid, <i>Togocyamus </i>(Pl. 1, figs. 1-5), appears in Paleocene strata. By the 
CENTERED	0006	295	60	1861	106	middle Eocene the highly specialized sand dollar had evolved. Until now it was believed that these 
CENTERED	0006	296	101	1862	149	developments required a long time from the Cretaceous through the Eocene. New evidence indicates 
CENTERED	0006	297	144	1862	189	that the change was much more rapid. In fact the change from a cassiduloid ancestor to a 
CENTERED	0006	297	183	1862	231	clypeasteroid probably occurred within the Paleocene; and the change from a primitive clypeasteroid 
CENTERED	0006	334	264	1866	309	The earlier 'Cretaceous' origin of the clypeasteroids was based on the supposed occurrences of 
CENTERED	0006	298	307	1861	353	three species of clypeasteroids in the Late Cretaceous. These occurrences are probably erroneous. 
CENTERED	0006	298	346	1863	392	One of the three species is too poorly preserved to be identified, and the stratigraphic data with the 
CENTERED	0006	299	387	1864	433	other two are inadequate. Extensive collecting has been done in the Late Cretaceous beds where these 
CENTERED	0006	299	428	1864	475	two species supposedly were found and neither Meijer (1965) nor Ernst (1972) have found any 
CENTERED	0006	299	469	1864	516	clypeasteroids. Ernst, in the course of his study, examined over 15000 echinoids from the Late 
CENTERED	0006	337	549	1865	595	The chronologically later origin of the clypeasteroids is supported by their absence from the 
CENTERED	0006	300	590	1865	633	Paleocene of the Western Hemisphere. An exhaustive search by <i>Kier </i>through washings of the 
CENTERED	0006	301	631	1865	675	Paleocene Vincentown, Aquia, and Clayton Formations (from which eighteen echinoid species are 
CENTERED	0006	302	672	1865	719	known) revealed no fragments that could be identified as clypeasteroid, although echinoid fragments 
CENTERED	0006	302	712	1869	759	are very common. It is noteworthy that the small fibularids, like those found in the Paleocene of 
CENTERED	0006	302	753	1866	799	Africa, were absent but normally would be expected in this material. They usually live buried in this 
FOLLOWED	0006	339	836	1866	880	The <i>earliest </i>confirmed clypeasteroid, <i>Togoeytrmus, </i>occurs in the Paleocene of West Africa. It 
CENTERED	0006	303	877	1867	921	<i>difiers </i>so markedly from all previous ecbinoids that there is disagreement as to its origin. Some 
CENTERED	0006	302	918	1865	962	workers consider the clypeasteroids to be <i>derived </i>from a holectypoid, but Phelan (1977, p. 419) 
CENTERED	0006	302	960	1866	1004	makes a strong case for their derivation from a juvenile stage of a cassiduloid. Its evolution must have 
CENTERED	0006	303	999	1868	1046	been extremely rapid and probably occurred within the Paleocene. The Late Cretaceous echinoid 
CENTERED	0006	304	1041	1866	1086	record is not only extensive but very well studied (Ernst 1972) and no intermediates have been 
CENTERED	0006	304	1082	1871	1122	found there. Current information indicates that the subsequent diversification and radiation of 
CENTERED	0006	304	1124	1868	1169	the clypeasteroids from a fibularid to a sand dollar occurred very abruptly (text-fig. 2) in the early part 
CENTERED	0006	305	1167	1869	1208	of the middle Eocene. Only two species, both fibularids, are known in the Paleocene: <i>Togocyamus</i>
CENTERED	0006	860	1372	1314	1401	<b>EXPLANATION OF PLATE </b>2 
CENTERED	0006	307	1427	1870	1471	Figs. 1-3. <i>Sismondia logotheti </i>Fraas. Early Eocene, from Siout (=Assiout), Egypt. 1, 2, 3, top, bottom, side 
CENTERED	0006	307	1502	1870	1546	Figs. 4-6. <i>Periardttts lyelli </i>(Conrad). Middle Eocene, Castle Hayne Formation, from North Carolina Lime 
CENTERED	0007	811	60	1306	93	K IER, <i>&lt;.lt.ntu~/4fitt, PertutY.Aur </i>
CENTERED	0007	807	106	1375	136	<b>PALAEONTOLOGY, VOLUME 25 </b>
CENTERED	0007	307	165	1876	216	<b><i>seefriedi </i>(Oppenheim) and <i>T. alloiteaui </i>Roman and Gorodiski. During the early Eocene the </b>
CENTERED	0007	305	206	1876	254	<b>clypeasteroids (text-fig. 2) were confined to Africa and India and consist of six species of fibularids </b>
CENTERED	0007	305	246	1875	295	<b>and two species of <i>Sismondia, </i>the most primitive member of the laganids. By the end of the middle </b>
CENTERED	0007	305	288	1875	339	<b>Eocene, the clypeasteroids had worldwide distribution with over 62 species representing 20 genera </b>
CENTERED	0007	487	616	686	652	<b>MIDDLE </b>
CENTERED	0007	479	667	693	706	<b>EOCENE </b>
CENTERED	0007	503	983	662	1021	<b>EARLY </b>
CENTERED	0007	473	1037	686	1076	<b>EOCENE </b>
CENTERED	0007	421	1376	731	1415	<b>PALEOCENE </b>
CENTERED	0007	425	1596	1725	1635	<b>rsxr-Ho. 2. Evolution and radiation of the clypeasteroid echinoid. The Paleocene </b>
CENTERED	0007	424	1631	1723	1677	<b>clypeasteroids are confined to%'est Africa and are a small, high species with incipient petals. </b>
CENTERED	0007	424	1669	1725	1711	<b>In the early Eocene they are more ilattened, have more-developed petals, and occur in Africa </b>
CENTERED	0007	423	1706	1723	1751	<b>and India, By the middle Eocene they are fully developed sand dollars and are present all </b>
CENTERED	0007	941	1749	1202	1777	<b>around the world. </b>
CENTERED	0007	325	1848	1860	1898	<b>The Cretaceous origin of the clypeasteroids was suggested by previous workers not only because of </b>
CENTERED	0007	289	1887	1855	1935	<b>the <i>supposed occurrence </i>of Cretaceous species, but also because it was believed that the Palaeocene </b>
CENTERED	0007	287	1929	1855	1977	<b>fibularids were not primitive enough to be ancestral to all later clypeasteroids. New information is </b>
CENTERED	0007	287	1971	1855	2019	<b>now available on Togocyamus. It is more primitive than previously thought and could be close to the </b>
CENTERED	0007	286	2013	1854	2062	<b>ancestral stock of all clypeasteroids. Although it has been assumed that its lantern supports were like </b>
CENTERED	0007	287	2051	1854	2105	<b>those found in later fibularids with each support composed of a single interambulacral plate, the </b>
CENTERED	0007	285	2095	1852	2145	<b>supports in <i>T. seefriedi </i>(Oppenheim) are both interambulacral and ambulacral in origin. Each </b>
CENTERED	0007	285	2136	1852	2186	<b>support ( text-fig. 3c) is formed by the extension of the primordinal interambulacral plate and the </b>
CENTERED	0007	285	2175	1849	2229	<b>adjacent half-ambulacral plates. This discovery is important for it has been suggested (Philip 1965, p. </b>
CENTERED	0007	285	2216	1852	2263	<b>58; Kier 1970, p. 105) that the clypeasteroids could be divided into two orders on the basis of the </b>
CENTERED	0007	283	2257	1850	2309	<b>character of the lantern supports. The suborder Clypeasterina includes all those clypeasteroids </b>
CENTERED	0007	816	2384	1354	2409	<b>KIER: ECHINOID EVOLUTION </b>
CENTERED	0007	983	2475	1126	2504	<b>EOCENE </b>
CENTERED	0007	951	3317	1157	3345	<b>PAL EOCENE </b>
CENTERED	0007	630	3385	1524	3418	<b>rsxT-sto. 3. The lantern supports in the clypeasteroids. c„ the </b>
CENTERED	0007	630	3421	1524	3457	<b>oldest clypeasteroid, the Paleocene <i>Togocyamus seefriedi </b></i>
CENTERED	0007	629	3458	1524	3493	<b>(Oppenheim) has lantern supports (indicated by a solid line) </b>
CENTERED	0007	628	3495	1523	3530	<b>composed of ambulacral (shaded) and interambulacral plates; </b>
CENTERED	0007	628	3531	1527	3566	<b>A, B, Eocene clypeasteroids have lantern <i>supports </i>composed of </b>
CENTERED	0007	628	3567	1524	3603	<b>interambulacral plates as in the suborder Scutellina (a) or </b>
CENTERED	0007	775	3606	1373	3640	<b>ambulacral plates as in Clypeasterina (n).</b>
CENTERED	0008	296	44	1859	86	having ambulacral lantern supports (text-fig. 3a); in the suborder Scutellina the supports <i>are </i>
CENTERED	0008	295	85	1859	124	interambulacral (text-fig. 3A). The presence of supports, both interambulacral and ambulacral in 
CENTERED	0008	295	126	1859	167	origin, in the oldest known and most primitive clypeasteroid adds weight to the supposition that 
CENTERED	0008	298	167	1859	208	<i>Togocyamus </i>is close to the ancestral stock of both suborders. By simply reducing the size of the 
CENTERED	0008	294	207	1858	249	ambulacral extensions and increasing the size of the interambulacral ones, supports could be 
CENTERED	0008	293	249	1857	291	produced that are typical of later species of the fibularids and the rest of the Scutellina. Conversely, 
CENTERED	0008	294	289	1857	325	the reduction in the size of the interambulacral and increase in the ambulacral extensions would 
CENTERED	0008	329	374	1857	412	A second discovery in <i>Togocyamus </i>is that its accessory pores are few in number and are restricted 
CENTERED	0008	294	415	1858	457	to the border of the ambulacra (Pl. I, fig. I). As pointed out by Durham (1966, p. U451), accessory 
CENTERED	0008	293	456	1856	497	pores are an exclusive feature of the clypeasteroids, occurring in all species. The fact that they are less 
CENTERED	0008	292	496	1854	536	well developed in this species than in any other is further evidence of the primitiveness of this form. 
CENTERED	0008	330	537	1856	579	In the light of the primitive features of <i>Togocyamus, </i>we can now postulate the evolutionary history 
CENTERED	0008	329	639	1856	677	1. The Paleocene <i>Togocyamus </i>(Pl. I, figs. 3-5) has a small, high test with its periproct in a primitive dorsal 
CENTERED	0008	292	676	1858	716	position, slightly developed petals with simple nonconjugate pores, a very erect lantern with supports of 
CENTERED	0008	292	714	1856	749	interambulacral and ambulacral origin. Its few accessory pores are confined to the borders of the ambulacra. It 
CENTERED	0008	325	789	1854	825	2, By the early Eocene, <i>Sismondia </i>(Pl. 2, figs. 1-3) has a larger, more fiattened test, a lower lantern, 
CENTERED	0008	291	825	1854	864	interambulaeral lantern supports, and a ventral periproct. The petals are better developed with conjugate pores; 
CENTERED	0008	783	970	1372	999	PALAEONTOLOGY, VOLUME 25 
CENTERED	0008	299	1040	1892	1075	3. The middle Eocene <i>Protoscute/la </i>and <i>Periurchus(PI. </i>2, figs. 4-6) are typical sand dollars having a large, very 
CENTERED	0008	263	1078	1891	1115	fiattened test, food grooves, very wide and low lantern, and a very small peristome. Accessory pores are spread 
CENTERED	0008	264	1116	1892	1152	all over the ambulacra, and the test is strongly reinforced by calcareous supports that are pierced by many canals 
CENTERED	0008	264	1154	1892	1191	for the water vascular system serving these pores. The adoral plate arrangement is now distinctive; there are far 
CENTERED	0008	264	1193	1891	1230	fewer and larger plates than in earlier clypeasteroids. As pointed out by Durham (1966, p. U450), these changes 
CENTERED	0008	264	1230	1892	1267	in the adoral plates result from the fiattening of the test. In fiattened species the number of plates on the adoral 
CENTERED	0008	264	1268	1889	1304	surface is determined at an early ontogenetic stage and thereafter growth is only by enlargement of the plates. 
CENTERED	0008	302	1327	1892	1368	The morphological changes that produced the sand dollar are specializations that enabled the 
CENTERED	0008	264	1369	1892	1408	echinoid to live more efficiently in sand (Seilacher 1979). The <i>flattened </i>test made it easier for the 
CENTERED	0008	264	1410	1892	1449	echinoid to burrow. The accessory tube-feet were used to pass sand over the top of the test and to 
CENTERED	0008	264	1451	1896	1491	convey food to the food grooves. The better-developed petals increased the respiratory capability of 
CENTERED	0008	264	1493	1892	1534	the petaloid tube-feet by increasing their area. The internal supports strengthened the test, enabling 
CENTERED	0008	265	1535	1892	1574	the sand dollar to live in environments of higher energy. The change from the erect lantern and large 
CENTERED	0008	264	1577	1892	1618	peristome in the primitive fibularid to the low lantern with horizontal teeth and small peristome in the 
CENTERED	0008	265	1619	1891	1659	sand dollar reflects a change in eating habits. According to Markel (1974, 1978; Markel, Gorny, and 
CENTERED	0008	264	1660	1891	1700	Abraham 1977) and Nichols (1959), the fibularid uses its lantern to scrape organic material from sand 
CENTERED	0008	265	1702	1892	1744	grains. This feeding method puts little stress on the teeth. The sand dollar, however, uses the teeth for 
CENTERED	0008	265	1744	1892	1786	grinding and chewing, The great stress can be withstood because the teeth are horizontal, and the 
CENTERED	0008	265	1787	1892	1827	stress is transmitted to the long axis of the teeth, The larger peristome in the fibularid permits the teeth 
CENTERED	0008	265	1829	1892	1868	to extend further out of the test to grasp food; in the sand dollar the sand is passed to the teeth within 
CENTERED	0008	304	1914	1892	1954	If it is true, as suggested herein, that the clypeasteroids originated in the Paleocene then all these 
CENTERED	0008	265	1956	1892	1997	changes necessary to derive a sand dollar from a cassiduloid ancestor occurred within 20 million 
CENTERED	0008	265	1998	1892	2040	years. Certainly there can be little question that the evolution from a fibularid to a typical sand dollar 
CENTERED	0008	265	2040	1891	2081	occurred between the beginning of the early Eocene and the latter part of the middle Eocene, a period 
CENTERED	0008	926	2188	1223	2216	<i>CONCLUSIONS </i>
CENTERED	0008	266	2249	1891	2291	The sudden appearance of the first irregular and the first clypeasteroid echinoids and their rapid 
CENTERED	0008	265	2292	1891	2330	diversification indicate a rate of evolution much faster than previously supposed. The mechanisms 
CENTERED	0008	265	2333	1891	2375	producing these great changes are uncertain, but the evolutionary steps must have been large. If each 
CENTERED	0008	266	2376	1892	2417	speciation event produced only small morphological change, than a multitude of transitional species 
CENTERED	0008	266	2418	1891	2457	would have resulted. The fossil record of the irregular echinoids is excellent (Kier 1977a). Even if this 
CENTERED	0008	266	2460	1892	2502	rapid evolution occurred in peripherally isolated populations, somewhere in the world we should 
CENTERED	0008	265	2503	1891	2542	have found more of these transitional species, I believe the absence of a large number of transitional 
CENTERED	0008	266	2545	1891	2586	species is explained not because they have not been preserved as fossils, but because they never 
CENTERED	0008	265	2586	1891	2626	existed. This conclusion supports Stanley's (1979, p. 212) statement that 'rates of evolution are 
CENTERED	0008	266	2628	1863	2670	highest early in adaptive radiation, when degree of divergence per speciation event is high...'. 
CENTERED	0008	266	2716	1891	2753	<i>Acknowledgments. </i>I thank Kenneth Towe and Thomas Wailer (Smithsonian Institution), and Thomas Phelan 
CENTERED	0008	266	2755	1890	2791	and Andrew Smith, for helpful discussions. The manuscript was read by Richard Boardman, Richard Grant, 
CENTERED	0008	266	2792	1892	2828	and David Pawson. I thank them for their suggestions. Mary Hurd Lawson did the light photography; Walter 
CENTERED	0008	266	2832	1892	2870	Brown did the SEM photography. Larry Isham made all the text-figures with his customary skill and 
CENTERED	0008	266	2870	1892	2907	inventiveness. Jean Roman (Museum National d'Histoire Naturelle, Paris) and Richard Jefferies (British 
CENTERED	0008	940	3018	1218	3045	REFERENCES
